title: Greek banks to be subjected to stress tests amid fears over capital levels

Sun, Aug 2, 2015, 16:13 BST - UK Markets closed Greek banks to be subjected to stress tests amid fears over capital levels By AFP | Telegraph – 1 hour 41 minutes ago 0.000 
Eyes on banks as Greek stock exchange to reopen 
Attention will be focused on Greece's embattled banks on Monday when the Athens stock exchange reopens after an absence of nearly a month because of the country's debt crisis. 
The banks are in a vulnerable position owing to outflows of billions of euros (dollars) from deposits over the past six months. 
Some €40bn (£28bn) has been withdrawn from Greek banks since December according to the bank association. 
And according to weekend reports, the top four lenders - National Bank (NYSE: NBHC - news ) , Piraeus Bank (EUREX: 21535576.EX - news ) , Alpha Bank (Other OTC: ALBWF - news ) and Eurobank - will undergo an asset quality review later this month. 
Stress tests will follow in the autumn to determine the recapitalisation requirements of each bank with European rescue funds. * US economist denies being part of 'criminal gang' over secret Plan B for Greece Greek officials want to complete the operation before new European regulations come into effect from January 1. 
As of 2016, bank shareholders and depositors will foot the lion's share of recapitalisation costs - a process known as "bail-in" - instead of European taxpayers. 
The stock market in the Greek capital closed on June 26, a few hours before Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras announced a referendum on the bailout conditions demanded by Greece's international creditors. 
The main index had closed at 797.52 points with a 2.03pc jump. 
Over that weekend, Greeks rushed to their banks' cash machines, prompting the government to impose capital controls from June 29, followed by the closing of the banks and the stock exchange. 
The aim was to protect the banking sector following the huge withdrawals by people nervous about Greece's economic and financial future. 
The banks reopened after three weeks on July 20 , but withdrawals and money transfers abroad remain under tight controls. Greeks can withdraw only up to 420 euros ($464) a week. 
The capital controls were slightly eased for businesses last week but economic activity, especially imports, continues to encounter numerous obstacles. 
Founded in 1876, the Athens stock exchange has closed down more than a dozen times in its history, the weekly To Vima reported Sunday, most recently in 2008 owing to a strike by Bank of Greece staff. 
Other instances include the Balkan Wars, the World Wars I and II, the Turkish invasion of Cyprus, 1987's "Black Monday" in the United States and the outbreak of a stocks manipulation scandal in 1996.
